Fig 8 Scheme 1 The illustration of CoNiSe/NC. Fig 9 Table 1 Comparison of the electrocatalytical performance of CoNiSe/NC-3 with recently reported electrocatalysts. Table 1 Electrocatalysts Overpotential (mV, HER) (mA cm−2) Overpotential (mV, OER) (mA cm−2) Potential for overall water splitting (V) (mA cm−2) Reference Co(S0.22Se0.78)2 175@10 283@10 1.63@10 [68] C0.85Se@NC 230@10 320@10 1.76@10 [69] CoO/CoSe2 337@10 320@10 2.18@10 [70] CoSe/CF2 95@10 297@10 1.63@10 [71] NiCoSe2-x /NC 89@10 340@10 1.53@10 [72] NiCoP/rGO 124@10 270@10 1.59@10 [73] Co-Ni-Se/C/NF 90@10 275@30 1.60@10 [74] CoNiSe/NC-3 100@10 270@10 1.65@20 This work Electrocatalytic water splitting at nitrogen-doped carbon layers-encapsulated nickel cobalt selenide Chuanlai Jiao Xiangjie Bo ⁎ Ming Zhou ⁎ Key Laboratory of Nanobiosensing and Nanobioanalysis at Universities of Jilin Province, Key Laboratory of Polyoxometalate Science of Ministry of Education, National & Local United Engineering Laboratory for Power Batteries, Department of Chemistry, Northeast Normal University, Changchun 130024, Jilin, China Key Laboratory of Nanobiosensing and Nanobioanalysis at Universities of Jilin Province Key Laboratory of Polyoxometalate Science of Ministry of Education National & Local United Engineering Laboratory for Power Batteries Department of Chemistry Northeast Normal University Changchun Jilin 130024 China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Generally, the catalytic overpotentials of hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) are unavoidable because of the low charge transfer. In this work, two strategies of alloying of Co with Ni and enclosing of electrocatalysts with carbonaceous materials were both used to accelerate the catalytic efficiency of cobalt selenide for water splitting. The nitrogen-doped carbon (NC) layer improves the reaction kinetics by efficient charge transfer. The alloying of metal into composited electrocatalysts can modify the electronic properties of host materials, thereby tuning the adsorption behavior of intermediate and improving the electrocatalytic activity. As expected, Nyquist plots reveal that the charge-transfer resistance (R ct) of nickel cobalt selenide encapsulated into nitrogen-doped carbon layer (CoNiSe/NC-3, Co:Ni = 1:1) are just 5 and 9 Ω for HER and OER, respectively, which are much lower than those of CoSe/NC-1 (Co:Ni = 1:0) (81 and 138 Ω) and CoNiSe/NC-3 without NC (CoNiSe-3) (54 and 25 Ω). With the high charge transfer and porous structure, CoNiSe/NC-3 shows good performance for both HER and OER. When current density reaches 10 mA cm−2, only 100 and 270 mV overpotentials are required for HER and OER, respectively. With the potential of 1.65 V, full water splitting also can be catalyzed by CoNiSe/NC-3 with current density of 20 mA cm−2, suggesting that CoNiSe/NC-3 could be used as replacement for noble metal electrocatalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract CoNiSe/NC as high effective electrocatalyst with good charge transfer property could catalyze water splitting with low potential and high current density, which could replace precious metals and achieve the application of renewable source. Keywords Nickel cobalt selenide Nitrogen-doped carbon layer Water splitting Hydrogen evolution reaction Oxygen evolution reaction 1 Introduction Hydrogen is considered as a renewable energy to replace tradition fossil energy [1,2]. Water splitting that produces mainly hydrogen at cathode and oxygen at anode is widely focused [3,4]. However, the overpotentials of hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) are unavoidable, resulting in more electricity than theory. Although noble metal catalysts such as Pt/C, IrO2, and RuO2 could catalyze the HER and OER effectively, the less storage on the earth limits application and contributes to the cost [5]. Therefore, searching for materials that are abundant on the earth and also could catalyze both HER and OER is desperately desired. Up to now, a lot of transition-metal electrocatalysts have been explored to catalyze HER and OER, such as metal sulfide, metal phosphide, metal nitride, and metal selenides [6–10]. Among these transition metal-based electrocatalysts, transition metal selenides show properties similar to those of transition metal sulfides because selenium is located in the same group with sulfur [11]. Therefore, transition metal selenides (CoSe2 [12], NiSe2 [13], ZnSe [14], CuSe [15] and Cu2Se [16], etc.) have received much interest from the researchers as electrocatalysts in water splitting, recently [9]. For example, nickel foam-supported NiSe/NiFe prepared by two-step hydrothermal method could catalyze water splitting effectively [17]. Only 240 mV overpotential is required to drive OER current density of 100 mA cm−2, whereas the same current density for the HER is 276 mV in 1.0 M KOH. The synergistic effect from NiSe and NiFe layered double hydroxides leads to a highly efficient catalyst system for water splitting by achieving 10 mA cm−2 current density at only 1.53 V in a two-electrode alkaline electrolyzer. Compared with transition metal oxides, transition metal selenides and sulfides show metallic/electronic property due to small or zero bandgap [18,19], conductivity [20] thereby enabling a higher performance than the corresponding transition metal oxides. However, in electrocatalytic application, the catalytic activity of transition metal selenides and sulfides [21] for water splitting remains relatively low performance in comparison to carbon matrix-supported or encapsulated transition metal selenides and sulfides. Carbon materials could greatly enhance electron penetration because the carbon supports tune the electronic structure of the transition metal selenides and sulfides, resulting in fast electron transfer rate and the high catalytic activity. A plenty of carbonaceous materials were used to improve the charge transfer property of the catalysts in water splitting, for instance, metal organic framework-based carbonaceous materials (MOF) [22], reduced graphene oxide (rGO) [23–26], and carbon nanotubes (CNTs) [27–29]. Electrocatalysts which are loaded on carbonaceous materials have been recognized as an alternative catalyst due to its high charge transfer [30]. In 0.1 M KOH, CoSe2 nanobelts anchored on nitrogen-doped reduced graphene oxides afforded a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at a small overpotential of 366 mV for OER [31]. Although these strategies could improve the charge transfer, the direct deposition of metal selenides on the outer surface of carbon materials usually suffer from the aggregation or the abscission of catalysts [32,33]. In this work, two strategies of alloying and encapsulation of CoNiSe into nitrogen-doped carbon layers (CoNiSe/NC) were mixed to improve electrocatalytic activity obviously. The former strategy modifies the electronic properties of composted electrocatalysts and improves the intrinsic activity, whereas the latter strategy accelerates the electron transfer during water splitting. Different to the supporting metal selenides, the latter strategy could prevent the aggregation of nanoparticles effectively. Furthermore, the unique structure offers more active sites and electron could transfer through the intermediary carbon. In addition, lots of channels could be available to release hydrogen/oxygen, which improves the stability of the electrocatalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and reagents All reagents in this study were analytical grade and without further purification prior to use. Cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O), nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O), potassium hydroxide (KOH), selenium powder, isopropyl alcohol (C3H6O) and N(CH2OOH)3 (NTA) were gained from Aladdin company. 2.2 Synthesis of CoNi-NTA-x complexes 1.50 g of Co(NO3)2·6H2O, 1.50 g of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, 0.90 g of NTA and 20 mL isopropyl alcohol (C3H6O) were mixed into 40 mL distilled water and stirred for 30 min into homogenous solution. Next, the solution was put into the Teflon tube. The Teflon tube was sealed in stainless steel and maintained at 180 °C for 6 h. After cooling the stainless steel down to room temperature, the precipitant was washed three times with mixture of distilled water and ethyl alcohol, and subsequently dried under vacuum at 60 °C. Then, pure CoNi-NTA-3 was got. Co-NTA-1, CoNi-NTA-2, CoNi-NTA-4, and Ni-NTA-5 were synthesized in the same way but the mass ratios were different (Co:Ni = 3:0, 2:1, 1:2, and 0:3). 2.3 Synthesis of CoNiSe/NC-X The as-prepared samples of Co-NTA-1, CoNi-NTA-2, CoNi-NTA-3, CoNi-NTA-4, and Ni-NTA-5 were loaded in ceramic boats, respectively, and 1.00 g selenium powder was placed 0.50 cm away from the boats at the downstream side. Afterwards, the ceramic boats were put into a tube furnace (quartz). Then the furnace was purged with nitrogen with flow of 1000 sccm. Next, the sample was pyrolyzed at 500 °C with a ramping rate of 5 °C min−1, and maintained at this temperature for 3 h. Finally, the furnace was frozen down to room temperature and then the CoSe/NC-1, CoNiSe/NC-2, CoNiSe/NC-3, CoNiSe/NC-4, and NiSe/NC-5 was obtained. 2.4 Synthesis of CoNiSe-3 CoNi-NTA-3 was put into furnace and heated at 500 °C under the atmosphere of air with a rate of 5 °C min − 1 for 3 h. And then, the sample was treated with H2 gas at the temperature of 500 °C for 3 h. After that, the sample was treated with the same process of selenization with CoNiSe/NC-3. 2.5 Electrochemical methods The morphology of powder was characterized by scanning electron microscope (SEM) (Hitachi SU8010 SEM) and transmission electron microscope (TEM) (JEOL JEM-2100 TEM). X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were collected by an X-ray D/max-2200vpc (Rigaku Corporation, Japan) instrument operating at 40 kV and 20 mA by using Cu radiation ( λ = 0.15406 nm ). X-ray photoelectron spectrum (XPS) was processed by thermos ESCA LAB spectrometer (USA). All electrochemical experiments were performed by Par 2273 Potentiostats Workstation at room temperature. The carbon rod was used as the counter electrode and Ag/AgCl electrode (3 M KCl) was used as the reference electrode. 20 µL of 3 mg mL−1 CoNiSe/NC-3 in Nafion (0.5 wt%) was casted on 0.5 × 0.5 cm2 carbon cloth as cathodic electrode for HER and anodic electrode for OER. The loading amount is estimated to be 240 µg cm−2. The carbon cloth was treated in 6 M HNO3 for 12 h to remove the oxide of the surface of carbon cloth [34]. 3 mg mL−1 Pt/C and 3 mg mL−1 RuO2 were modified on 0.5 × 0.5 cm2 carbon cloth with the same loading amount for comparison under the same conditions. The (linear sweep voltammetry) LSV curves were recorded in 1.0 M KOH (30 mL) electrolyte at a scan rate of 5 mV s−1. All currents presented are not corrected against the ohmic potential drop. Electrochemical impedance Spectroscopy (EIS) was also obtained in 1.0 M KOH (30 mL) electrolyte on a Par 2273 Potentiostats Workstation. 3 Results and discussion The synthesis progress of the CoNiSe/NC-3 is illustrated in Scheme 1. With the aim of observing the morphology and structure of CoNiSe/NC-3 and CoNi-NTA-3, the SEM measurements of CoNiSe/NC-3 and CoNi-NTA-3 were conducted (Fig. 1 ). As indicated in Fig. 1(a), spherical balls which consist of nanosheets could be observed. Specifically, some interconnected pores in the range of 100–150 nm are visible in the CoNi-NTA-3. And Fig. 1(b) shows that the thickness of CoNi-NTA-3 is about 10–15 nm. From Fig. 1(c), upon the selenization, CoNiSe/NC-3 remains the almost identical sphere structure of CoNi-NTA-3 except rough surface. Additionally, the thickness of CoNiSe/NC-3 nanosheets is thicker than before (Fig. 1d), indicating the composition evolution during the selenization. Unlike the sheet structure of CoNi-NTA-3, some convex caps are found in the surface. The same phenomenon also occurs on CoSe-NTA-1, CoNiSe-NTA-2, CoNiSe-NTA-4, and NiSe-NTA-5 (Fig. S1). After the progress of selenization, their structures are basically remained. The SEM of CoNiSe-3 was also conducted and it shows similar structure to that of CoNiSe/NC-3 (Fig. S2). To further confirm the change of CoNiSe/NC-X, the nitrogen sorption isotherms of CoNiSe/NC-X were tested. As shown in Fig. S3, N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of CoNiSe/NC-3 and CoNi-NTA-3 show obvious hysteresis loop in the range of 0.8–1.0, indicating the presence of macropores [35]. The Brunauere-Emmette-Teller (BET) of CoNiSe/NC-3 is calculated to be 121 m2 g−1, which is bigger than that of CoNi-NTA-3 (107 m2 g−1) due to more channels produced by selenization. The CoNiSe/NC-3 shows a wide pore size distribution from 50 to 100 nm. From the nitrogen-sorption data in Fig. S4, the BET surface areas of CoSe/NC-1, CoNiSe/NC-2, CoNiSe/NC-4, and NiSe/NC-5 are calculated to be 18, 42, 55 and 64 m2 g−1. The comparison of surface area among the five samples illustrates that BET value of CoNiSe/NC-3 is the biggest, contributing to the exposure of active sites. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image could probe the structure and elemental distribution. In Fig. 2 (a), nanoparticles are uniformly embedded in carbon layer. Fig. 2(b), (c) is high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images. The values of crystal lattice are 0.271, 0.182 and 0.340 nm, which correspond to characteristic lattice planes (101) and (100) of CoNiSe2 and (111) of carbon respectively [36,37]. By using energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectrum (Fig. S5), the presence of Co, Ni, Se, N and C is indicative the presence of selenides and nitrogen-doped carbon. The uniform distributions of Co, Ni, Se, N and C of CoNiSe/NC-3 could be observed clearly in Fig. 3 . However the use of single carbon layer-coated copper grid results in the content of C more than it actually is. With the aim of offering a proof of the existence of CoNiSe2 compound, X-ray diffraction (XRD) was conducted (Fig. S6). Fig. S6(b–d) shows XRD patterns of CoNiSe/NC-2, CoNiSe/NC-3, CoNiSe/NC-4, indicating that CoNiSe2 compound was successfully synthesized (JCPDS 65-7038). However, new peaks at 44.22° and 75.85° in Fig. S6(b) and peaks at 51.67° and 76.09° in Fig. S6(d) appeared, indicating that residual Co/Ni was observed in the form of pure metal Co/Ni (Co 15-0806 [38]; Ni 89-7128 [39]). The character peaks appear at 28.24° and 32.93°, which refer to crystal planes (100) and (101) of CoNiSe2. As shown in Fig. S6(a, e), Co0.85Se/NC (JCPDS 52-1008) [40] and Ni0.85Se/NC (JCPDS 18-0888) [41] were also obtained. As comparison, the electrocatalyst without N-doped carbon layer (CoNiSe-3) was also tested in Fig. S6(f), which also shows the characteristic diffraction peaks for CoNiSe2. The differences of Co0.85Se, CoNiSe2 and Ni0.85Se could be further seen in Fig. S6. The main characteristic peaks of Co0.85Se are 33.26°, 44.74°, 50.56° and 61.87°; the main characteristic peaks of CoNiSe2 are 32.93°, 44.41°, 49.99°, 59.60°, 61.17° and 69.07°; the main characteristic peaks of Ni0.85Se are 33.15°, 44.95°, 50.49°, 60.24° and 61.80°. The patterns of XPS in Fig. 4 were employed to probe the composition and chemical state of CoNiSe/NC-3. Fig. 4(a) shows the signals of Co, Ni, Se, N, C and adventitious O. In Fig. 4(b), the peaks at 853.8 and 871.5 eV of Ni 2p represent the binding energies (BEs) of Ni 2p 3/2 and Ni 2p 1/2, respectively [42,43]. The peaks at 855.6 and 873.1 eV are attributed to Ni-O bonds, which can be ascribed to the surface oxidization of metallic Ni and peaks at 853.8 and 871.5 eV are corresponding to Ni-Se [44]. Two satellite peaks of Ni 2p region appear at 861.2 and 879.6 eV [45]. The two spin orbit-doublets at 780.6 and 796.5 eV of Co 2p could be clearly observed in Fig. 4(c). They refer to Co 2p 3/2 and Co 2p 1/2, representing Co-Se bonds [46,47], together with two satellite peaks at 786.3 and 803.0 eV [48]. The peaks at 782.2 and 799.5 eV refer to Co–O bonds [49]. Fig. 4(d) shows that the peaks at 400.0, 401.2 and 402.3 eV are assigned to pyridinic N, pyrrollic N, and graphitic N [50]. As shown in Fig. 4(e), the presence of peak at 54.3 eV indicates the presence of Se. However the signal at 58.6 eV is attributed to oxidization of Se. Metal selenides is easy to be oxidized by the oxygen of air and therefore the surface of CoNiSe/NC-3 contains more SeO x . Infrared spectroscopies of CoNiSe/NC-3 and CoNi-NTA-3 were conducted to observe the changes of composition before and after the process of selenization (Fig. S7). The peaks of 1418, 1689, 2087 and 3421 cm−1 are respectively assigned to the stretching vibration of C–H and C=O [51]. The stretching vibration of the coordinated carboxylate group of Co(II) [51], and the N–H of NTA [52] decreased sharply because of conversion of NTA. During the process of selenization, functional groups of NTA are decomposed or changed to carbon layer [53]. EIS was tested to demonstrate whether the strategies work or not. First, we explored if the content of Ni could influence the resistant of catalysis. Fig. 5 (a) shows the R ct of CoSe/NC-1, CoNiSe/NC-2, CoNiSe/NC-3, CoNiSe/NC-4 and NiSe/NC-5 in 1.0 M KOH electrolyte for HER at 10 mA cm−2 are 58, 31, 5, 38 and 48 Ω, respectively. It is easy to conclude that the doped Ni can make the resistances change. Alloying of Co and Ni atoms is an effective method to enhance charge transfer ability more easily due to synergistic effect, which contributes to performance of CoNiSe/NC-3 [54]. Next, the resistance of CoNiSe-3 and CoNiSe/NC-3 was compared. As shown in Fig. 5(b), the resistance of CoNiSe-3 for HER is larger than that of CoNiSe/NC-3. The carbon layers enclosing the CoNiSe nanoparticles are in favor of charge transfer. Therefore, the strategies of doping Ni and coating carbon layer could facilitate catalysis with high charge transfer. As such, EIS of CoSe/NC-1, CoNiSe/NC-2, CoNiSe/NC-3, CoNiSe/NC-4 and NiSe/NC-5 for OER are 138, 100, 9, 54 and 126 Ω respectively (Fig. 5c). Fig. 5(d) shows that R ct of CoNiSe/NC-3 for OER is almost one-third less than that of CoNiSe-3. Next, the effect of charge transfer ability on electrocatalysts of HER and OER was studied. Fig. 5(e–f) illustrates that when current density reaches 10 mA cm−2, the overpotential of CoNiSe-3 is 250 and 350 mV for HER and OER, respectively, higher than the overpotentials of CoNiSe/NC-3 (100 mV for HER and 270 mV for OER). Different contents of Ni could also affect the performance for both HER and OER. We can observe from Fig. 6 (a) that all the samples could catalyze HER effectively. When CoSe/NC-1, CoNiSe/NC-2, CoNiSe/NC-3, CoNiSe/NC-4 and NiSe/NC-5 were used, the values of potentials at current density of 10 mA cm−2 are just 165, 128, 100, 149 and 196 mV, respectively. It is convenient to observe the resistances and overpotentials of CoSe/NC-1, CoNiSe/NC-2, CoNiSe/NC-3, CoNiSe/NC-4 and NiSe/NC-5 for HER at current density of 10 mA cm−2 from Fig. S12. The value of CoNiSe/NC-3 for HER is close to that of Pt/C (61.2 mV) (Fig. 6b). Bimetallic synergistic effect could make full use of exposed active sites. Tafel slope is main parameter of electrochemical H+ reduction [55]. From Fig. 6(c), Tafel slopes of CoSe/NC-1, CoNiSe/NC-2, CoNiSe/NC-3, CoNiSe/NC-4, NiSe/NC-5 and Pt/C are 98.0, 79.0, 66.5, 97.4, 105.0 and 60.9 mV dec−1 respectively. At first, with the alloying of Ni atoms, considerable alloying advantage of CoNiSe/NC could increase the intrinsic electronic conductivity and/or enlarge the surface area of the resulted catalysts, which may modulate the Gibbs free energy (ΔG) of H abs absorption and free energy of water dissociation to form adsorbed hydrogen in Volmer step [56]. Then, too more Ni atoms decrease the synergistic effect. According to the theoretical calculations [57,58] the incorporation of Ni lowers the free energy for atomic hydrogen adsorption on edge Se sites of CoSe2 and in turn allows high intrinsic HER activity. Additionally, the curves of CoSe/NC-1, CoNiSe/NC-2, CoNiSe/NC-3, CoNiSe/NC-4, and NiSe/NC-5 under different scan rates of 50, 60, 70, 80 and 90 mV s−1 are used to calculate electrochemical double-layer capacitances (C dl) which is measured to evaluate the electrochemical surface area (ECSA) of the catalysts (Fig. S8) [59]. Fig. S9 shows that the ECSA values of CoSe/NC-1, CoNiSe/NC-2, CoNiSe/NC-3, CoNiSe/NC-4 and NiSe/NC-5 are 10.3, 17.5, 38.6, 17.5 and 7.7 µF cm−2, respectively. Large ECSA value of CoNiSe/NC-3 illustrates that more active sites are exposed to electrolyte, which enhances the catalytic performance [60]. As shown in the Figs. S10–S11, the electrochemical active surface area-normalized LSV shows the same trend for HER and OER catalysis, in which the CoNiSe/NC-3 shows the superior activity, suggesting that CoNiSe/NC-3 shows a high intrinsic activity for both HER and OER. The stabilities of CoNiSe/NC-3 and Pt/C were tested by the method of chronoamperometry at potential of − 100 mV (Fig. 6d). CoNiSe/NC-3 shows better property of stability for catalyzing HER. During the time of 12,000 s, the current density of CoNiSe/NC-3 is almost no reduction. In contrast, a little attenuation of commercial Pt/C could be seen. Encapsulation of CoNiSe in nitrogen-doped carbon layer reduces the effect of behavior of hydrogen bubbles, which also contributes to stability. Generally, the reaction step of HER is the initial Volmer step accompanied with Heyrovsky or Tafel steps [61]. The observed Tafel slope of 66.5 mV dec−1 for CoNiSe/NC-3, and therefore the possible pathway for HER on CoNiSe/NC-3 catalysts is through Volmer–Heyrovsky reaction mechanism. As demonstrated in previous work, HER catalytic efficiency in alkaline media is also dominated by ΔG of water dissociation to form adsorbed hydrogen in Volmer step [58]. Accordingly, perhaps the Ni alloying could accelerate the Volmer step in an alkaline electrolyte. CoSe/NC-1, CoNiSe/NC-2, CoNiSe/NC-3, CoNiSe/NC-4 and NiSe/NC-5 could also directly decrease the potential for OER (Fig. 7 a). As shown in Fig. 7(b), CoSe/NC-1, CoNiSe/NC-2, CoNiSe/NC-3, CoNiSe/NC-4 and NiSe/NC-5 could catalyze OER in 1.0 M KOH solution at current density of 10 mA cm−2 with the overpotentials being just 350, 320, 270, 330 and 340 mV, respectively. For the comparison, RuO2 also was used as electrocatalyst for OER in the same solution and show the overpotential of 310 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2. Therefore, CoNiSe/NC-3 shows better performance for OER than RuO2. For comparison, the resistances and overpotentials of CoSe/NC-1, CoNiSe/NC-2, CoNiSe/NC-3, CoNiSe/NC-4 and NiSe/NC-5 were listed in Fig. S13. Fig. 7(c) shows Tafel slopes of CoSe/NC-1, CoNiSe/NC-2, CoNiSe/NC-3, CoNiSe/NC-4, NiSe/NC-5 and RuO2 are 98.0, 78.7, 60.5, 85.0, 103.0, 61.3 mV dec−1 respectively. Similar to HER, low Tafel slope of CoNiSe/NC-3 indicates that CoNiSe/NC-3 exhibits effective electron transfer property in OER too. Stability is another important property of electrocatalyst. From Fig. 7(d), with the overpotential of 270 mV, the stabilities of CoNiSe/NC-3 and RuO2 were tested. Good stability of CoNiSe/NC-3 at current density of 10 mA cm−2 could be found and the current density of RuO2 decreases with the time sharply. Theoretical results indicated that OER activity is main dependent on the energetics of OER intermediates (OH−, O⁎, and HOO⁎) on the catalysts surface. Then, after the Ni doping, the Co-Ni bimetallic selenides possess a high adsorption energy adsorption energy of OH− than that of Co3Se4 and NiSe, suggesting that alloyed selenide is more favorable for adsorbing OH− and thus promote OER catalysis [11]. With the increase of Ni content, the synergistic interplay decreases, thereby showing low electrocatalytic ability. Our result is well consistent with the previous publications [62,63]. And the control experiment of CoNi-NTA-3 has been used to support the conclusion in Fig. S14. The precursor shows low activity towards both HER and OER catalysis. As shown in Fig. S15, the SEM, XRD and XPS measurements of CoNiSe/NC-3 were conducted after 20,000 s for HER and OER. As indicated in Fig. S15, both of the SEM images after HER and OER test show identical morphology to that of CoNiSe/NC-3 (Fig. S15), indicating good stability. And also, the XRD patterns show almost the same diffraction peaks for the CoNiSe/NC-3. However, the comparison between the XPS spectra reflects that after OER reaction the content of Co–O, Ni–O and Se–O configurations are higher than those after HER catalysis, respectively. In alkaline solution, after long-term catalysis, the surface of metal selenides is vulnerable to surface oxidation for OER [64]. To achieve potential application of CoNiSe/NC-3 for overall water splitting, two electrodes in 1.0 M KOH (CoNiSe/NC-3||CoNiSe/NC-3) were tested. For comparison, commercial Pt/C and RuO2 were fabricated on carbon cloth, which assembles full cell: Pt/C||RuO2 (Fig. 8 ). We can observe that CoNiSe/NC-3||CoNiSe/NC-3 shows potential of 1.65 V at current density of 20 mA cm−2 (Fig. 8a), which is much lower than 1.68 V of Pt/C||RuO2. Fig. 8(b) shows that current density of 20 mA cm−2 of CoNiSe/NC-3||CoNiSe/NC-3 (1.65 V) and Pt/C||RuO2 (1.68 V) is both kept after 12,000 s. However current density of Pt/C||RuO2 decreases with the increase of time, CoNiSe/NC-3||CoNiSe/NC-3 shows better stability. More comparisons were done and listed in Table 1 . The electrocatalytic performance of CoNiSe/NC-3||CoNiSe/NC-3 is comparable to or even better than the reported electrocatalysts, suggesting the potential application of CoNiSe/NC-3 as alternative electrocatalyst for water splitting. The good performance for water splitting may be attributed to reasons as below: (1) Not only the charge transfer could be improved by encapsulation of CoNiSe into nitrogen-doped carbon layers, but also aggregation of CoNiSe2 nanoparticles could be avoided, resulting lower influence of kinetic factor [65]; (2) Ni alloying could accelerate the Volmer step in an alkaline electrolyte and improve the catalytic activity [66]; (3) large value of BET area is helpful to make a connection between electrocatalyst and electrolyte, favoring the availability of active sites and accelerating the rate of HER and OER [67]. Furthermore, desorption of hydrogen and oxygen could be easily released by using lots of channels in CoNiSe/NC-3. 4 Conclusions Carbon coating and bimetallic coordination can increase the activity of electrocatalysts effectively. The resistances of CoNiSe/NC-3 are only 5 and 9 Ω for HER and OER, respectively, which are lower than those of CoNiSe-3. Furthermore, the effects of improved charge transfer on electrochemical behaviors for HER and OER were also explored. As a kind of good electrocatalyst for HER and OER, more conductive CoNiSe/NC-3 shows the high catalytic activity. When CoNiSe/NC-3 was used to catalyze HER and OER, the overpotentials at current density of 10 mA cm−2 in 1.0 M KOH are just 100 and 270 mV respectively. Full water splitting could be catalyzed by CoNiSe/NC-3 with the potential just 1.65 V at the current density of 20 mA cm−2. As the electrocatalysts of overall water splitting, CoNiSe/NC-3 also shows good stability, which could be potential to replace precious metals and pave the way to achieve the application of renewable source. coredata.dc:description: Generally, the catalytic overpotentials of hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) are unavoidable because of the low charge transfer. In this work, two strategies of alloying of Co with Ni and enclosing of electrocatalysts with carbonaceous materials were both used to accelerate the catalytic efficiency of cobalt selenide for water splitting. The nitrogen-doped carbon (NC) layer improves the reaction kinetics by efficient charge transfer. The alloying of metal into composited electrocatalysts can modify the electronic properties of host materials, thereby tuning the adsorption behavior of intermediate and improving the electrocatalytic activity. As expected, Nyquist plots reveal that the charge-transfer resistance (R ct) of nickel cobalt selenide encapsulated into nitrogen-doped carbon layer (CoNiSe/NC-3, Co:Ni = 1:1) are just 5 and 9 Ω for HER and OER, respectively, which are much lower than those of CoSe/NC-1 (Co:Ni = 1:0) (81 and 138 Ω) and CoNiSe/NC-3 without NC (CoNiSe-3) (54 and 25 Ω). With the high charge transfer and porous structure, CoNiSe/NC-3 shows good performance for both HER and OER. When current density reaches 10 mA cm−2, only 100 and 270 mV overpotentials are required for HER and OER, respectively. With the potential of 1.65 V, full water splitting also can be catalyzed by CoNiSe/NC-3 with current density of 20 mA cm−2, suggesting that CoNiSe/NC-3 could be used as replacement for noble metal electrocatalysts.

coredata.dc:title: Electrocatalytic water splitting at nitrogen-doped carbon layers-encapsulated nickel cobalt selenide
